title: The Broken Covenant
shortSummary: Jeremiah 11 records God's solemn reminder to Judah and Jerusalem about the covenant made with their ancestors, warning of the consequences of disobedience and idolatry. The chapter highlights the people's rebellion, the resulting judgment, and Jeremiah’s personal peril due to his prophetic message. It underscores the seriousness of covenant faithfulness and the certainty of divine justice.
timeline: c. 627-586 BC - Late 7th to early 6th century BC, during Jeremiah's prophetic ministry before the Babylonian exile

keyCharacters.name: Jeremiah
keyCharacters.description: The prophet who receives and delivers God's message of covenant warning and judgment to Judah and Jerusalem.

keyCharacters.name: The men of Judah and inhabitants of Jerusalem
keyCharacters.description: The people addressed by Jeremiah who have broken God's covenant and turned to idolatry.

keyCharacters.name: The men of Anathoth
keyCharacters.description: Jeremiah’s own townsmen who conspire against him and seek to silence his prophetic voice.

outline.heading: God’s Covenant Command and Warning
outline.description: God instructs Jeremiah to remind Judah and Jerusalem of the covenant made at the Exodus, emphasizing obedience as the condition for blessing and possession of the promised land.

outline.heading: Call to Obedience and Rejection of the Covenant
outline.description: Jeremiah is commanded to proclaim the covenant publicly, but the people persist in disobedience, following the evil inclinations of their hearts.

outline.heading: Conspiracy and Covenant Breaking
outline.description: God reveals a conspiracy among the people who have returned to the sins of their ancestors, breaking the covenant by serving other gods.

outline.heading: Judgment Announced for Covenant Breach
outline.description: God declares inevitable judgment that the people cannot escape, highlighting the futility of idolatry and the breaking of the covenant.

outline.heading: Jeremiah’s Peril and Divine Justice
outline.description: Jeremiah reveals his knowledge of a plot against him by his own townsmen, yet he entrusts his cause to God, who promises to punish those who seek his life.

application: Recognize the seriousness of God’s covenant and strive to obey His commands fully as a demonstration of faithfulness.
Avoid the temptation to follow the 'imaginations of the evil heart' by continually seeking God’s guidance through prayer and Scripture.
Trust God’s righteous judgment and justice, even when facing opposition or persecution for standing firm in the truth.
Do not intercede for persistent unrepentance but pray for a heart change that leads to genuine repentance and restoration.

keyVerses.text: And say thou unto them, Thus saith the LORD God of Israel; Cursed be the man that obeyeth not the words of this covenant,
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the solemn warning that disobedience to God’s covenant brings a curse, emphasizing the gravity of faithfulness.

keyVerses.text: Therefore thus saith the LORD, Behold, I will bring evil upon them, which they shall not be able to escape; and though they shall cry unto me, I will not hearken unto them.
keyVerses.significance: It reveals the certainty of divine judgment and the consequences of persistent rebellion against God.

keyVerses.text: But, O LORD of hosts, that judgest righteously, that triest the reins and the heart, let me see thy vengeance on them: for unto thee have I revealed my cause.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights Jeremiah’s trust in God’s righteous judgment and his plea for vindication amid persecution.
